This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE METRIC SYSTEM
div.p: According to Reuter's telegram of Thursday, the adoption of the metric Nystem by the firm of Messrs. Kynoch Limited, of whose board Mr. Arthur Chamberlain is chairman, has fallen as a bomb upon the commercial world of Great Britain. Mr. Chamberlain expresses the opinion that the firm is only anticipating

general reformation which must soon come in England, and mys that they are thereby reducing the cost of their calculations and in creasing their export trade. The telegram, however, does not make clear to what ettent the metric system (in the literal and original meaning of the word "metric") has been adopted. A few years ago "metric" system was suggested with an inch unit as basis, and we remain in ignorance as to whether the firm has adopted the inch or the metre unit. No worse method for weighing and measuring than the one which has held sway in England for centuries could be conceived, and scientists were long since compelled to discard it and base all their calculations upon the infinitely more rational metric system. That system has stood the test of use satisfactorily, whereas ours has proved most clumsy and detrimental to our trade with foreign countries. The general adoption of the metric system into our country could be effected with very little cost and labour were the inch to be taken as the unit of length, but the entire changing of the inch unit would be very costly and a great obstrue. tion to the introduction of the more scientific system. Assuming, therefore, that we are about to adopt the metric system, which we should have done very many years ago.--the question still remains, what shall we take as our unit ! A uniformity of systems and units would greatly simplity interchange of trade between us and other countries, but can it be obtained? There are indeed two methods by which such a consommation could be reached. The first, and the one to which we incline the more readily, is that the inch unit should be adopted in the metric system, and that the some 550,000,000 people who use it should force the 150,000,000 people who use the metre unit to adopt the former. The second method is the adoption of the metre as a length unit by Greater Britain, which would be a terrific sacrifice. It is not the adoption of the metrie system which would prove a diffi culty, but the adoption of the metre length unit. The clumsinesss and impractibility of our systems of calculations are universally recognised, and reform is, therefore, greatly to be desired, but we would hardly counsel the adoption of the metre unit. A nation who divides a square pole into thirty and a quarter square yards, who follows such a system of recording temperatures, the bare mention of which makes a scientist shud. nder, indeed whose every mathematical calcula. tion is ridiculously laborious, must be content to run an uneven race. It behoves us, there. fore, to adopt the general decimal system used by other countries.

Up to 1897 the irregular and arbitrary nature of the British standards was enforced by law, but in August of that year Parlia ment sanctioned the use of the metric system, which up to the present no British firm has been sufficiently courageous to adopt. In the metrie system there are five principal units, those of length, ares, volume, capacity, and weight. The unit of length is the metre; the unit of area is the square metre; the unit of volume is the cubic metre; the unit of capacity is the litre, which is one-tenth of a metre ; and the unit of weight is a gram, i.e. the weight of water contained in one-thousandth of litre. Such is the system which we ought to adopt, with the exception that the inch should take the place of the metre. The whole system is based upon a single measurement of length and from it we can find out by simple calculation the weight of known volumes of different substances. But the English system has the dis advantage of being variable as well as arbitrary, as is instanced by the existence of two hundred different weights for weighing corn, as an example of which we might note that 46 Sutherland pounds of an equal 240 Cornish pounds. Lord Kelvin denounced the English system as time wasting and brain-destroying in its confusions, and we heartily agree with him. These are not the only disadvantages, Many firms have to spend hundreds of pounds

year in the necessary transcription of English weights and measures to the metrical system mnd vice versá, and, moreover, England is continually losing orders owing to her bad system, In many,and probably in the majority of cases, the prices of competing firms differ very little, and the question of convenience invulved in che use or non-use of the metric system may easily decide who gets the order.

div.p: The transport Braemar Castle is due at| Alexandria with reliefs for the British Garrison on the 13th December.

div.head: Re: about The Plague.
div.p: Kamel To day's bulletin reports the admission to in the bospital at Cairo of one case of plague and two deaths, one of which was pneumonio.

div.p: The Alexandria Manicipality will begin ito sales of the new quay estate on the first Thursday after the Bayram bolidays. Pive lots will be pat ap for sale.

div.p: M. Dag ont, director of the Cairo Tramway In Company, we retarged from leave, and is now morni busy with the organisation of the new Shonbrab Musta and Zaptieh lines.

div.p: sald The time of closing of the mail for Barope, on via Port Said and Brindisi, at the G.P.O., ind Alexandria, has been altered from 3.10 p.m. to S.S. a.m. tomorrow.

div.head: Cattle Imports.
div.p: Large numbers of osttle are being exported from Asia Minor hither via Smyrna, where there are at prosent considerable herds and Alocks at Bourdova awaiting shipment.

div.p: The "Mokattam" state that in consequence of the rooont incidents at Al Azhar, thirty of the ulems of that University intend to draw fever Lord Cromer's attention to the matter.

div.head: Coptio Recoaroh.
div.p: Professor Dr. Scbmidt, the well-known authority on Coptic and early Christian archeology, has been staying at Cairo for the past two months for the purpose of research. He is leaving Egypt by the S.S. Hobenzollern on the 23rd inst.

div.head: Now Roumanian Line

div.p: On the 18 October 14 vesaolo, of which 5 were Dorthward aod 9 southward boond, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 433,430.49. Of those 8 were British, 2 German, Japanese, 1 Dutch, and 1 Austrian The total receipts since October 1 are Pr. 5,006,363.82, and during that time 49 vessels transited the canal, 80 being northward, and 103 southward boond.

div.head: Revolting Tragedy at Port Sald. c
div.p: Yesterday morning, the Port Said police found the desd body of a new-born male obild on the shore close to the bathing sheds. Every thing points to the bratal murder of the infant, the head, which was wrapped round with a handkerchief, bearing several contusions. Searching investigations are being made with * view to fioding the child's mother, who is suspected of having foally murdered ber newborn offspring.

div.head: Ceography for School Uno.
div.p: Mr. Ahmed Hafez bao poblisbed a third edition of his geography which he specially compiled for use in Ezyptian schools. This book is intended for the papils of the third and fourth primary years and is in accordance with the latest syllabus drawn up by the Ministry of Edaoation. lo this edition the geography of Egypt and the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan has been onlarged, and the s'atistics of commerce and population are scoording to Ir the most recent and reliable returns.

div.head:
KAMEL'S INCORRUPTIBILITY.
KAMEL'S INCORRUPTIBILITY.
REPLY TO "AL MOKATTAM.".
div.p: Re the pleasant tales that have been going about as to the diminution of Mustapha Pasha Kamel's salary we hote the following paragraph in the "Lews":-

The nation knows the political opinions of "Al Lewa," and all are aware that its director is not one to refrain from expend- iture drawn from his capital or his profits. Had he received pecuniary assistance from any quarter he would have said so, but he works for his country and not for himself. We have nothing bat scorn for the base insinuations." Sancta simplicitas!
In reference to the above, we have this morning received the following telegram from Mustapha Pasha Kamel:-

I entirely contradict what "Al Mokattam" stated to the effect that "Al Lewa" draws a salary or any financial support from Turkey on any other country. "Al Lewa" is a wholly independent paper, and it is impossible for any person to ascertain the contrary. "Al Mokattam's" versions about the native Egyptians are entirely unfounded and not worth to be quoted in the esteemed papers. MUSTAPHA KAMEL.

div.head: NATIVE PRESS ON MR. BLUNT.
div.p: "Al Watan" says: No one has yet criticised Lord Cromer like this original Englishman, the fevered eccentric, Mr. Wilfred Blunt. No one has attacked him with such violence and vigour. Some Egyptians regard Mr. Blant as an intellectual phenomenon. The majority regard him as an oddity, and as being incapable of giving any advice that can be accepted with profit. The hatred and malice of this strange personage have led him at last to write an article to the "Figaro" containing a scandalous personal attack on Lord Cromer. The latter, according to Mr. Blaut, has always aimed at annexation by devious and unworthy intrigues. Our readers can be trusted to form their own opinion of this writer. He is simply an eccentric, whose opinions and literary productions merit no consideration whatever. The very extravag ance of his onslaughts can only be of ad vantage to Lord Cromer, who returns to Egypt stronger than before.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday evening the Khedive held reception at Ras el-Tin Palace on the occasion of the beginning of the month of Ramadan. It was largely attended.
After the reception his Highness left Ras el- Tin for Montazah at 11 o'clock. He is spending the day at the latter palace.

div.head: THE RELIGION OF ISLAM.
div.p: A useful book on the Mohamedan religion has been published by Messrs. Kegan Paul, Trench, Trübner and Co. (78. 61). The author is the Rev. F. A. Klein, who was appointed by the Church Missionary Society to Cairo in 1882, and the chief subjects treated are the sources, the doctrines, the Imamste, figh, and the sects of Is'am. The work is a very handy compendium of the main points of this religion and should be useful as a work of reference, but unfortunately it is not provided with an index.

div.head: THE WAKFS.
div.p: The Superior Council of the Wakfs, at its last meeting, approved of the lease of 1,126 feddans of land in the village of El Safieh, and of 1,402 feddan", with an increase of £2,916 on last year's rental.

The Council postponed until next meeting the question of the indemnity to be paid to the Alexandria Municipality in connection with the lands expropriated in this town for the construction of a theological university, similar to Al Azhar.
The "Zaher" states that the Wakfs Admini- stration contemplates creating a special medical service.

div.head: THE SUDAN
div.p: Sir Rudolph Satin leaves Cairo to-morrow for Khartoum. In the course of his general inspection he will be accompanied to Kordofan by the Sirdar, who will return to Khartoum by the White Nile. Slatin Pasha will meet on the frontier of Darfour the delegates of Sultan Aly Bey Dinar, and will oross the hills of Nubia on his way back.

div.head:
FRONTIER COMMISSION.
RETURN OF MEMBERS.
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fathy, Mr. Wade, and the escort attached to the Frontier Commission are expected to arrive early this afternoon at Cairo from Suez. Miralai Owen Bey and Naoum Bey Shakeir are travelling across the peninsula from Muerak, via Port Nakhl, to Saez. The members of the Commission are all in good health.

div.head: MILITARY RECONNAISSANCE.
div.p: Yesterday's General Orders of the Army of Occupation contains the itinerary of the forth- coming reconnaissance through the Delta of a squadron of the 6th Inniskilling Dragoons.

The squadron, which will be accompanied by an officer of the Royal Engineers and of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, will leave Cairo on the 23rd inst. in two detach- mente, one proceeding to Benha and the other to Belbeis, whence they will both proceed on the following day to Zagazig. Here the two detachments will join forces and leave on the 25th for Simbellawein. Subsequently the equad- ron will visit Mansourah on the 26th, Sama- noud on the 27th, Tantah on the 28th, Shibin- el-Kom on the 29th, and Ashmoun on the 30th, returning to Cairo on the 31st.

Major A. C. Fox, R.A.M.C., will leave Alexandria for Cairo on Tuesday next for duty with the squadron during the reconnaissance. An advance party of an officer and 18 men with two railway tracks conveying supplies will precede the troops.

div.head: JANE HADING'S VISIT.
div.p: Mme Jane Hading will give her first repre- sentation at Alexandria on the 13th of Novem ber, and on the 17th of that month she will open at Cairo, where six plays will be staged, and she will then return here to give another five representations, from November 23 to 27, inclusive. On the 28th November she will leave for Smyrna, and will afterwards visit Constan tinople and Roumania. Her company consists of well-known French artistes from the Odéon, Gymnasium, and Sarah Bernhardt theatree. Her repertoire includes Sapho, Maitre de Forges. Chatelaine, Retour de Jerusalem, Princesse Georges, Petite Marquise and Demi Monde.

div.head: FREEMASONRY.
div.p: At the meeting of the "Quatuor Coronati Lodge," No. 2876, held in London on the 5th inst, Bro. Joseph Sakakini Bey was unanim- ously elected a member of that Lodge. We congratulate Sakakini Bey on his nomination, which is a tribute to his popularity as a
mason.
A new masonic lodge, called "El Radja," has been formed in Cairo, under the auspices of the Grand Lodge of Jerusalem. The W. M. is Constantin Bey Canello.

div.head:
ESBEKIEH GARDENS THEATRE.
"LA DAME DE CHEZ MAXIM."
div.p: This well-known farcical comedy was given last night to a well-filled house and proved a great attraction. It is an extremely funny play, the situation at times being very cleverly arranged, though in some cases somewhat risquée, and might not be appreciated by an English audience. All the same everybody seemed highly pleased with the piece, and the audience went away in the best of hamours. We must confess to having had some doubts as to the Gardet company being up to the average, judging from a visit we paid to this theatre shortly after their arrival, but we have no hesitation in saying that the company last night showed vast improvement on the previous. efforts, besides being strengthened by the addi-, tion of a most valuable recruit in the person of Mlle. Berthe Chantenay, who is a host in ber- self. She acted and sang admirably throughout, ber impersonation of the leading part being well nigh perfect. She favoured us with couple of songs during the second act which called forth loud applause, though we are cer- tain that half the audience did not grasp the meaning of the second one, consisting mostly of Parisian slang; albeit it appeared to greatly amuse those who understood.
Apart from Mme. Bellanger, M. Smits, and M. Lacroix, all of whom contributed to the success of the piece, not mach can be said of the rest, who were only moderately good.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Pharos sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here next Monday evening or Tuesday at daybreak, with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Ellerman S.S. City of Oxford arrived at Liverpool from Alexandria yesterday morn- ing, making the voyage in 12 days. The Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern left Naples yesterday, and is due at Alexandria on Monday morning at nine o'clock with passengers and general cargo.

div.head: TURKISH TROOPS IN TRIPOLI.
div.p: Turkish troops from Fezzan have arrived at Djanet, in the Tripoli vilayet. According to telegrame received here, Turkish reinforcements from Tripoli have halted close to the territory under French protection. Orders have been given to strengthen all the advance posta round this territory. Many Tarkish troops have encamped at Sheikh Said, despite the fact that the Djanet incident has been settled with the French Government.
Costanza to Alexandria,

I learn that the inauguration of the new line of the Roumanian Maritime Service be- tween Constanza and Alexandria will take place on the 20th inst. The service will be carried out by the Imperial Trajan and the Roumania, which are two of the fastest and best- equipped mail steamers afloat. The departure from Constanza will be every Thursday, half- an-hour before midnight and from Alexandria every Friday at 6 pm.
Visit of Solentists to Cairo.

Under the auspices of "La Revue Général des Sciencies", a visit of scientists to Egypt is being organised for the coming season. One party of these tourists will spend their whole time in Egypt and another will only visit Cairo and the Delta generally, after which they will proceed to Palestine, Galilee, Damascus. Baalbeck, and Cyprus.
Local Rate of Interest,
A soheme is now under consideration at the Ottoman Ministry of Justice for lowering the legal rate of interest from 9 to 7%, to meet the growing market needs.
Agricultural Bank.
The Ottoman Agricultural Bank has opened branches in the vilayet of Tripoli in Africa. Its rate is 4%
Personalla,

Preparations have been made for the recep- tion at Constantinople of his Beatitude Mgr. Photios, Greek Patriarch at Alexandria, who will confer with his colleague at Constantino- ple on questions affecting the Alexandria patriarchy.
Mgr. Neotoriu, who has been appointed Vicar General of the Orthodox Greek Patriarch of Alexandria, was received in farewell au- dience of the Boumonical Patriarch before leaving Stamboul for Cairo.
The marriage has taken place here of M. Leon Molho, a founder of the Saul Modiano bank at Salonica, to Mlle Ester Assayas, of Cairo.

div.head: NEW ARABIC LADIES' JOURNAL.
div.p: Patat el-Sherk" ("The Young Woman of the Orient") is the title of a new ladies' month- ly, which has just appeared in Cairo, under the editorship of Miss Labibeh Hashim, the well- known Syrian lady writer. The first issue of "Fatat-el-Shark," which makes the third re- view published in Egypt, contains some very interesting artioles. In her introductory notes the editress states: "Of Arabic journals there are many, but they are edited by men, and there is plenty of scope for female literatore in this country A man can write about a woman what he knows and thinks of her, but a woman can write about herself what she believes or feels."

div.head: THE CAIRO POLICE.
div.p: A Cairo contemporary reports that the day before yesterday a native ticket-collector on one of the Nasrieh trains took money from two passengers without giving them tickets. The inspector, who is a Frenchman, detected this and boxed the man's ear. A scene followed and, accorded to our confrère, two shawishes and an agent of the secret police appeared, and on learning what was the matter seized the Frenchman and held him tight while he was pommelled by the ticket-collector. The inter- vention of Captain Lo Schiavo and a kawass of the French Consulate put an end to this disgraceful scene. We sincerely trust that if enquiry proves the details as reported to be true, the policemen will receive exemplary panishment.

div.head: ZAGAZIG ASSIZES.
div.p: The Assizes Coart of Zagazig has sentenced to ten years' penal servitude one of the bur- glars who, three months ago, entered the dwelling of a well-known Sheikh of Port Said, Youssef Attala by name, and under threat of death, obliged the sheikh and his wife to give up all their valuables, consisting of £7 and jewellery.

The burglar, who was arrested as the result of a careful search instituted by the Native Court, received on the morrow of his arrest a letter from one of his relatives, who expressed therein his inability to accept an invitation to take part in the said robbery. Th's, and his identification by the Sheikh's wife, was suffi cient to cou vict him.
The Zgazig Assizes has also condemned to three years' imprisonment an Abyssinian domestic of Port Said for violence and outrage committed on the person of a Syrian maid-servant.

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: MAITRE ZAJA
We regret to announce the death of Mattre Zaja, formerly bâtonnier of the Mixed Bar at Alexandria.

At the opening of the sitting this morning at the Mixed Civil Court, under the presidency of Judge Pangalos, Maitre Avlonitis made an eulogistic speech on the merits of the deceased. Judge Pangalos replied on behalf of the Bench in sympathetic terms.
RENÉ CARTON DE WIART.

We greatly regret to learn of the death of Mr. Réné Carton de Wiart, governor of Tourah prison, which has taken place at Naples. Mr. Réué de Wiart was only 39 years of age, and during his many years of Government service. in this country he made himself very popular with all communities. He served in the Belgian army previous to coming to Egypt, where he was first an officer of the mounted police. For his Egyptian services the Khedive conferred upon bim the orders of the Osmanieh and the Medjidieb, and he recently received the decoration of Chevalier of the Order of Leopold. Mr. Réné de Wiart will be greatly missed in Cairo, where his circle of friends was very wide. He was a strict disciplinarian, and on one occasion was able put down in person an out- break on the part of the convicts of Toursh prison. He was extremely popular with all his colleagues, and subordinates. It is reported that the cause of his death was an abscess on the liver, for which disease he was treated at Carlsbad. We offer our sincerest sympathy to his widow and family.

div.head: RICH ANGLO-GREEK'S WILL
div.p: Mr. Basil Metaxas Vagliano, of 16, Dawson- place Bayswater, and of Mesars. Vagliano Brothers, Winchester House, Old Broad-street, merchants, who died on September, 30, leav ing a fortune of £197,224, gives to his wife Mrs. Charicles Basil Vagliane £ 200 and the use for life of his house and furniture; to his sister Dramantina Panaghi Rossolimos an annuity of 1,200 Greek drachmas; to his niece Calomina Frangopulo 600 drachmas a year; to his brother Athanasius Metaxas Vagliano £200; and to John Hollams, jan., £200. During her widowhood his wife is to receive one fifth of the income from his residuary, estate, and subject thereto everything of which he shall die possessed is to be held in trast for his daughter Danaë.

div.head: GERMAN EGYPTOLOGISTS.
div.p: The Egyptological mission of the Berlin Museum will commence its campaign this season early in December at Eshmounair, near Assiout. Afterwards operations will begin in January at Elepbantine.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Auiourd'hui à midi et demie.)

A la suite de l'élévation du taux privé d'es- compte de 4 7/3 à 5 7/8% en Angleterre, notre corbeille des valeurs a ouvert déprimé et en baisse générale notable. Peu après, cependant, il y a eu reprise, et la clôture s'effectue en fermeté relative.
Les transactions ont porté en particulier sur l'Agricole, la National Bank, la Cassa di Sconto, la Delta Land, la Nile Land, les Estates et le Crédit Franco-Egyptien.

L'Agricole fléchit de 9 27/329 13/16, la Delta Light de 12 1/16 à 11 7/8, la Daira de 16 13/16 à 16 11/16, la Bébéra de 39 1/2 à 391/4, la Salt and Soda de 23/9 à 23, l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 337 à 336 1/2, la Cassa di Soonto de 234 1/2 à 233, les Nangovich Hotels de 18 à 17 7/8, la Delta Land de 3 13/16 à 3 25/39, la Nile Land de 16 7/16 à 16 1/8, l'Or dinary Khedivial Mail de 35/10 1/2 à 35/9, la Land Bank de 9 1/32 à 8 15 16, le Trust de 1 15/32 1 7/16, les Estates de 2 3/32 l'Urbaine de 6 13/32 à 6 3/8 vendeurs, la Building Lands de 5 1/32 à 5 et le Crédit Franco Egyptien de 5 13/32 à 5 3/8. Tandis que l'action Comptoir se raffermit 6 99/32 l'ancienne et 6 5/8 la nouvelle, la part de fondateur réactionne d'une livre à 48. Par contre, la Privilégiée Tramways d'Ale xandrie remonte de 187 à 189 1/2, les Cotton Mille de 5/10 1/2 à 6, et la Banque d'Orient de 136 1/2 à 137.
La Bière d'Alexandrie gagne 10 francs d'avance à 220-995, sans que d'ailleurs des affaires aient été traitées.
Une grande demande n'a cessé de prévaloir en Union Foncière, mais le prix se maintenant à 6 1/4 les acheteurs attendent une meilleure occasion.

Malgré l'accentuation de la pénurie moné taire à Londres, ici on reste généralement opti- miste. Une grande partie de l'or retiré de la Banque d'Angleterre eet, en effet, destinée à l'Egypte et ca fait est évidemment favorable.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Prince Hassein Pasha Kamel paid a visit yesterday morning to Lord Cromer at the British Agency.
Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affair, in expected to return to Cairo from Barope in the first week of next month.
Masloum Pasha is expected to return from Earope on the 28th inst.

The marriage was solemnized at New York on the 29:h alte of Mrs. Ethel Hanson, (Countess Bosdari) and Birch Pasha, manager of Sir E. Cassel's irrigation works in Egypt. Birch Pasba and Mrs. Birch will spend the winter at Cairo.

Miralai K. B. Macauley Bey, C.M.G., who has been recently appointed Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, will arrive at Cairo to-morrow from the Buden. The question of the appointment of his successor has not yet been decided.
Mr. Rowlatt, governor of the National Bank of Egypt, will sail on the 31st inst. from Marseilles for Egypt.
Judge Satow has arrived at Alexandria, and will succeed Judge Arober on the local Bench at the end of this month.
Lord Lanesborough, who is in Egypt with the Coldstream Guards, will remain here daring the winter. Lady Lanesborough has already come out to Cairo.

We hear that M. Sootides, Greek Consul General at Alexandria, will in all probability suboeed M. Philon at Constantinople, and will be replaced at Alexandria by M. Caclamenos, a well-known author and publicist.

Mr. J.B. Cornish, C.M.G., managing director of the Alexandria Water Company, who is at present staying at Bellagio, on the Lake of Como, will return on the 29th inst. by the Austrian Lloyd steamer from Trieste.
Mr. Bonham Carter, Legal Secretary to the Sadan Government, has arrived in Cairo from Khartoum, and yesterday morning had an interview with the Sirdar. Mr. Carter is pro- ceeding to India on leave.
The Dean and Mrs. Butoher are due at Port Said to-morrow, and are expected to arrive at Church House, Cairo, on Monday.

Mr. George Gottlieb, barrister-at-law, has returned to Cairo from his holiday in England, and resumed his practics. Mr. and Mrs. Gottlieb, who were accompanied by their little daughter, travelled by the S.S. Ophir.
Mr. James Curry, director of Sadan Educa tion is staying at Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo.
F
Kaymakam Hussein Bey Sherif and Kaima- kam Ibrahim Bey Sabri, of the Recruiting Department, will probably retire on pension in the near fatare.
M. Maximoff, Russian Minister at Cettigne, and one-time Agent at Cairo, and Mme Maxi- moff are now in Constantinople. They were lately at Carlsbad.
Sir Julius Wagner has arrived in Cairo, and is staying at Shepheard's Hotel.

Count Stadnicki, accompanied by Mr. Ewald Falls, after paying a visit to the German exon- vations at Karm Abu Mina, the site of the Convent of St. Menas in the Maríout country, has left on a trip to Wadi Natrun, where he will visit the ancient Coptic monasteries.

Hanna Bey Bacoom and all the members of his family beg to tender their heartfelt thanks to all those friends who were so kind as to attend the funeral, and to send their sympathy by letters, cards, or telegrams, for the loss of his beloved son, Sawa Bacoom.

The Earl of Denbigh, who celebrated the coming of age of his eldest son, Viscount Feilding, last Friday, was formerly a captain in the Royal Artillery, and served in the Egyptian campaign of 1889. He was present at the battle of Tel-el-Kebir. He is the ninth Earl of Denbigh and eighth Earl of Desmond, and he is also Viscount Callan, Viscount Feilding, Baron Feilding, and Baron St. Lis. He was born in 1859, and educated at Oscott College and the Royal Military Academy at Woolwich. From 1897 to 1901 he was a Lord- in-Waiting to the late Queen Victoria, and has since served in the same capacity to his Majesty the King. He went as Special Envoy to Rome on the occasion of the jubilee of Pope Leo XIII. in 1901. The eldest son, Viscount Feilding, was born on October 12, 1885, and educated at the Oratory School, Birmingham, and at Christ Church, Oxford.

div.head: BRITISH POSTAL ORDERS.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, - With reference to the paragrapb "Britisb Postal Orders" published in your com bar of the 18th inst, allow me to call be attention of those of your readers, who may possibly employ postal o.ders us remittances, to the fast that, if they want to avoid trouble. they should not fail to register the letter in which the orders are encored. My reason for saying this is that a few weeks ago I wrote to the postmaster in Cairo, reporting that a postal order I had sent to a firm in Malta was never reoaived by them. I therefore requested that payment sbould be stopped, but, in spite of my mentioning the bomber of the counterfoil, which is still in my possession, the reply from tbe Postal Alministration was to the effect that "The Post Office is not responsible for the loss of the order in question as it was sent by ordinary post instead of registered." Uo. Hortonately the amount was only for a few shillings, otherwise, I would have adopted other wensures towards the Postal Adminis tratioo, who is reaping the benefit of an amount whioh bas not been paid to tbeir debit.-Yours truly,

div.head: JOINTS SHAPBLESS WITH RHEUMATISM
div.p: The Patient, a Man of 75, also Suf.
fered from Lumbago, Sciatica, Dizziness and Pains in the Head,

Urinary Disorders, and Gravel. Mr. William Davis, 96, Brereton Road, Rugeley, England, says : -"I am 75 years old, but I am not too old to have found out how good Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are. They have brought me great comfort, and I can highly recommend them.

"My work has always exposed me to the weather, and many a time I have got wet through to the skin. In my own mind I have no doubt that this is what brought on the sciatica and lumbago from which I first suffered 12 years ago. I was confined to my bed for a long time, and the agony I underwent was terrible. I also had rheumatism, and my joints were shapeless with it.

. "Occasionally my head was so bad that I was light headed; many a time I have come over so dizzy that, but for some handy support, I should have fallen. The kidney secretions were scalding in passing, and full of gravel.
"After trying all manner of cures,' and spending pounds on doctors' medicine, without getting any relief, I went under hospital treatment, yet I could no get well.

"I had read a good deal about Doan's Back ache Kidney Pills, and my friends had urged me to try them, so at last I got some, and by the time the first box was finished I was certainly better. Encouraged, I went on with the medicine, and now I can truthfully say! that it is many a long year since I felt so well as I do to day. I can take quite a long walk without exhaustion -a thing I had not been able to do for years before I began with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills."
Doan's Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at 13 P.T. per box.

div.head: JOINT SYSTÈME BUHNE
div.p: pour manchons de tuyaux d'eau et de gaz.
Manchon d'un tuyau de 3 mm de diamètre rende Hanche par la laine de plomb Buhne et sur la
une profonde 30 Atinospheres
JUAGU'présent on assemblait les manchons de tuyaux en introduisant tout d'abord une tres de chanvre et en coulant du plomb dans la partie restée vie, puis on mata le plomb coulé.

Notre nouveau système de raccord étanche se comporte wut autrement. Nous employons au lieu de plomb fondu la laine du plomb brevetée en tres es de 1 m de longueur et pesant t oul kilog. suivant les manchons, et procédons summe suit :

Après avoir tout d'abord introduit et comprimé la treenederhanvre, on prend une tresse de laine de plomb ou une partie seulement de la trese, selon la force du joint, on learvule autour du tuyau et on la mate fortement dans le manchon ; on répete l'opération jusqu'à ce que le manchon soit complètement plein et bien maté. Par le fait que le matage commence déjà au fond du manchon . . directement sur la troos do chanvre. la laine de plomb we transforme en une FRAASE homogene, su moyen de laquelle on realise non seulement une étanchéité parfaite, mais encore résistance bwaunup plus considerable qu'auparavant.

Des essais de notre nouveau systeme de raccordement étanche ont ét faits nun wulement dans no urines, mais ausRien beaucoup de villes qui en font l'étude a différents points de vue. Ainsi nous avons réalisé des joints de tuyaux de 300 et 450 m de diamètre d'apre notre procédé et wiumis ces joints pendant des semaines à une pression constante de 20 atmospheres que le raccord cedat. On réunit galernt i bouti bout 4 tuyaux de 100 mm de diametre d'après notre procédé : on plaça les doux extrémités sur deur supports de telle sorte que la partie intermédiaire ne fût pas soutenue. On ne constata ainsi aucune flexion. Par contre un owai analogue avec des joints en plomb fondu acum une flexion considérable.
next ainsi démontre qu'anec notre procede on obtient un joint bien étanche et une résistance mécanique bien plus grande qu'autrefois.
Notre nouveau procédé de raccordement étanche offre en outre l'immense avantage de permettre de travailler par tous les temps et sans nécessiter la mise a se des manchons.
Outre ces énormes avantages techniques, notre procédé présente vis-à-vis des anciens prookle encore d'autres

L'appareil encombrant pour le coulage plomb el mupprimé, et avec le tout le combustible tel que bois coke ; la perte de plomb à la coulée est toutee, UN pprune de même le suhde, la main dawere de moulage des této de manchons et la main d'entre de coulage.
Dans notre procédé il ne faut plus que des mateurs,
Il s'ensuit que notte méthode rend le travail plus économique que l'ancien prooide, sans parler den avantages concernant l'hygiene. AUG. BUHNE Co.,
Agent Général pour l'Egypte Fribourg, Brisgau

are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."
"Investments" (148 pages) sent Post Free on mentioning "Egyptian Gazette."

Nous détachons d'une lettre d'Alexandrie, en dato d'hier, le passage suivant:

De même qu'au Caire, on a 88sayé de faire ici un mouvement sur la Salt and Soda on affirmant que la fusion de ootto Société avec la Port-Said Salt .Agzsociation pourrait être d'ores et déjà, considérée comme on 'fait ac. compli. Or, suivant des renseignements poisés

bonne source, tel ne serait pas précisément le cas. Certo, la fusion serait désirable dans l'intérêt des deux Compagnies; mais il est patent qu'elle serait plus avantageuse pour la Salt and Soda que pour la Port-Said Associa tion. Aussi bien celle-ci ne croit-elle en droit de poser ses conditicps. Bo attendant, la preuve que rien n'est encore décidé, c'est que les ao tions de la Port-Said restent à 16 ab. 9, alors qu'elles auraient du bénéficier les première d'un mouvement si le fait allégué était véridique."
Le dom benéticolataire pour

Il est avéré que l'Bryptian Land and General Trust Ltd. (Hooker) a vendo sa propriété de Goorbal à un groupe à la tête doquel se trouvent MM. Rossano Prères et Cie, J. Po maroli et autres. L'affaire laisse exactement av Trost on bénéfice de £ 40,000.

Le domaine de Gourbal, sis Alexandrie, entre lo canal Mahmoudieb, les quartiers Mo | barrem Bey et Attarine et la Gare du Caire, a one superficie de 334,000 pics carrés, dont Jes 65% appartenaient au Tront. La vente aurait eu lieu à raison de P.B. 60 le pie.
"Le groupe acquéreur se propose de lotir le terrain en petites parcelles à l'effet d'y faire construire des habitations économiques.

Pour ce qui est de l'Egyptian Land and Go. neral Trust, on rapporte que la Sciété aurait l'intention de répartir à ses actionnaires on di videode intérimaire, avant de faire l'appel des 10 shellings non encore versés sur les titres.
On prétend, on outre, que la Socié é serait en train de négocier une affaire appelée à lui valoir un courtage important; mais des ron seignements préois funt encore défaut 100 sujet.
